Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Atmospheric measurements of O2/N2 ratio, CO2 concentration, and CO2 isotopes in support of the Arctic Observing Network
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will support a continuation of time series measurements of atmospheric CO2 concentration, the stable isotopes of CO2, and the O2/N2 and Ar/N2 ratios of air samples collected at Arctic sampling stations. Measurements of O2/N2 ratio at Arctic sites, when also combined with measurements at lower latitudes, have the potential to help quantify the magnitude of the seasonal air-sea exchanges of O2 with the Arctic Ocean, which could be a key indicator of biogeochemical change in a time of rapid Arctic warming. Although the land biosphere also contributes to seasonal variations in O2/N2 ratio, the ocean contribution can be resolved by combining O2/N2 and CO2 data to compute the tracer atmospheric potential oxygen (APO), which is effectively an atmospheric tracer of ocean biology and chemistry. This work will draw on support from international collaborators, with the potential to shape Arctic O2/N2 measurements by the international community into a critical component of the AON. Measurements of the 13C/12C ratio and 18O/16O ratio at Arctic sites also may provide key early warning indicators of ecological change. The project will support the archiving of aliquots of atmospheric CO2 in background arctic air to be used for open-ended purposes by future researchers. Finally, the project will support graduate student involvement in the collection and foster collaborations among scientific groups engaged in measurements of O2 and CO2 isotopes in support of detecting Arctic change.

Institution.Name: University of California-San Diego Scripps Inst of Oceanography

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported measurements of changes in atmospheric oxygen and carbon dioxide in air samples collected at arctic stations. These measurements are the continuation of long-term records, extending back to the 1960s in the case of CO2, and the 1990s in the case of oxygen. The measurements document the ongoing global rise in CO2 and decline in O2. The data also document seasonal cycles, which are also changing. In the case of CO2, the data show that a major increase in the amplitude of the CO2 cycle has occurred since the 1960s and has continued over past decades. This increased amplitude is an indicator that boreal and arctic ecosystems have undergone major changes, in the direction of increased summer-time photosynthesis and winter respiration. This project indirectly supported interpretive work that helped to understand the relationship between changes seen in the atmospheric records and changes also seen by satellite observations. In the case of O2, the records are shorter and the changes are more nuanced. Whereas the CO2 cycles are predominantly caused by exchanges with land ecosystems, the O2 cycles are caused by combined influences of both land and ocean. The ocean influence on the O2 cycles can be resolved from sum O2+CO2, which is not influenced by land photosynthesis but is still influenced by O2 exchanges with the ocean. This project supported interpretive work to study the changes in this sum, which is also known as "atmospheric potential oxygen", APO.   At artic stations, APO tends to rise in the spring and summer, when the high-latitude oceans release O2 produced by marine photosynthesis.  APO tends to decrease in the fall and winter, as cooling of the sea surfaces causes deep mixing which exposes O2-depleted deeper waters to the surface.  The observed cycles in APO provide a broad-scale, regionally-integrated metric of both these processes, and the changes in the APO cycles offer a means of detecting and evaluating changes in these processes over time. The records supported by this project generally show a trend towards earlier phasing of the APO cycles, but trends in the amplitudes are different at different stations. The earlier phasing may be consistent with declining sea ice coverage and later freeze-up, which allow for earlier and stronger releases of O in the spring and increased uptake of O2 by the oceans in the fall. The values of these records continues to grow with time, as they help quantify the profound changes that are occurring in boreal and arctic ecosystems, both on land and in the oceans, with our changing climate.
